cards.back: A simplified mathematical representation of a physical system that captures essential behavior while deliberately ignoring less important details.

cards.front: When should you use a lumped model vs distributed model?
cards.back:
Lumped model: when physical dimensions << wavelength (λ/10 rule).
Distributed model: when dimensions are comparable to wavelength.

λ = c/(f×√εr)

cards.front: What are state variables in a circuit?
cards.back:
Variables associated with energy storage elements:
• Capacitor voltage (vC)
• Inductor current (iL)

Number of states = number of independent energy storage elements

State equation: ẋ = Ax + Bu
Output equation: y = Cx + Du

Where x = state vector, u = input, y = output

cards.front: How to get transfer function from state-space?
cards.back:
H(s) = C(sI - A)⁻¹B + D

Poles are eigenvalues of A matrix
det(sI - A) = 0

cards.front: Steps to linearize a nonlinear system
cards.back:
1. Find equilibrium point where ẋ = f(x₀, u₀) = 0
2. Define perturbations: δx = x - x₀
3. Compute Jacobians:
   A = ∂f/∂x|₀, B = ∂f/∂u|₀
4. Linear model: δẋ = Aδx + Bδu

rd = VT/ID

Where VT ≈ 26mV at room temperature

Example: ID = 1mA → rd = 26Ω

Verification: Are equations solved correctly? (Math check)
• Convergence studies
• Manufactured solutions

Validation: Do equations match reality? (Physics check)
• Compare to measurements
• Physical intuition check

• Infinite open-loop gain
• Infinite input impedance
• Zero output impedance
• Infinite bandwidth
• Zero input offset voltage
• Infinite CMRR

cards.front: When does the ideal op-amp model fail?
cards.back:
• High frequency (finite GBW)
• Large signals (saturation, slew rate)
• Precision applications (finite gain)
• Low impedance sources (input bias current)
• High-speed transients (slew rate limit)

cards.front: George Box's famous quote about models
cards.back:
"All models are wrong, some are useful."

Meaning: No model perfectly represents reality, but good models are useful for prediction within their domain of validity.

cards.front: The two pillars of model building for circuits
cards.back:
1. Conservation Laws (universal physics)
   • KCL: Σi = 0 at any node
   • KVL: Σv = 0 around any loop

2. Constitutive Relations (component-specific)
   • v = iR (resistor)
   • i = C dv/dt (capacitor)
   • v = L di/dt (inductor)
